misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements (solving a different problem)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones. The entire structure of the solution (inputs, variables, calculation, and output) targets a physics formula rather than the required sum-of-evens task.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and computes the average acceleration (a = (v1 - v0) / t), then prints it.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process those inputs, check which numbers are even using n % 2 == 0, accumulate the sum of only the even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Program reads three double values instead of five integers.
No loop is used to process multiple inputs.
No conditional check for even numbers (no use of n % 2 == 0).
Output message reports 'The average acceleration is' instead of the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have reused or written code for a different assignment (average acceleration) and did not adapt it to the current specification about summing even numbers from 5 integers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and list the exact inputs, the required processing steps (looping over 5 numbers, checking evenness with n % 2 == 0), and the required output. Then design the program around those requirements rather than reusing code from a different problem.
related_concepts: Loops over fixed counts of inputs
Conditionals and modulus operator for even/odd checks
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program (prompts, variable names, formula, and output) aligns with an average acceleration problem and contains none of the required elements for summing even numbers from 5 integers.

evidence.snippet:
System.out.print ( "Enter v0, v1, and t: " ) ; // prompt

double v0 = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // starting velocity
double v1 = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // final velocity
double t = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // time

double a = ( v1 - v0 ) / t ; // compute acceleration

System.out.println ( "The average acceleration is " + a ) ; // output
evidence.note: The code clearly solves an average acceleration problem using v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers, looping, checking for even numbers, and summing them as required by the assignment.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that calculates average acceleration based on initial velocity, final velocity, and time, rather than the required program to read 5 integers and sum the even ones. The logic implemented solves an entirely different problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this code satisfies the requirement for Q1, which suggests that the wrong code was submitted or the problem statement was completely misunderstood.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading exactly five inputs, typically integers, and using iterative and conditional logic to calculate and output the sum of only the even numbers among those five inputs.
symptoms: Program calculates acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
Reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integer inputs
Lacks loop structure and conditional logic for even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student copied/pasted or wrote code for a different assignment/question and submitted it for Q1.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully review the instructions for Q1 (Sum of Even Numbers) and ensure the submitted code directly addresses those specific requirements, focusing on iterative input, conditional checks for evenness, and accumulating a sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely functional for calculating acceleration but bears no resemblance to the code required for summing even numbers from five inputs.

evidence.snippet:
System.out.print ( "Enter v0, v1, and t: " ) ; // prompt

        double v0 = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // starting velocity
        double v1 = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // final velocity
        double t = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // time

        double a = ( v1 - v0 ) / t ; // compute acceleration

        System.out.println ( "The average acceleration is " + a ) ; // output
evidence.note: The code prompts for and uses variables v0, v1, and t to calculate acceleration, not summing five integers.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Solved - Physics Formula Instead of Even Sum
misconceptions.description: The student has solved a completely different problem. Instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even numbers, the student wrote code to calculate average acceleration using the formula a = (v1 - v0) / t. This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a physics acceleration problem rather than a sum-of-even-numbers problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers, checking each one to see if it is even (divisible by 2), and summing only those even numbers. The output should be 'Sum of even numbers: X' where X is the calculated sum.
symptoms: Code reads 3 values (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers
Code calculates acceleration instead of filtering and summing
Output message is about acceleration, not sum of even numbers
No loop structure to process 5 inputs
No conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0)
No accumulator for the sum
misconceptions.root_cause: Complete misunderstanding of the problem statement. The student may have been working on a different assignment or copied code from another problem without reading the actual requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task is to: (1) Read 5 integers from user input, (2) Use a loop to iterate through all 5 numbers, (3) Check if each number is even using the modulo operator (n % 2 == 0), (4) Add even numbers to a running sum, (5) Print the final sum with the message 'Sum of even numbers: X'
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: This is extremely high confidence. The submitted code solves a completely different problem (physics acceleration calculation). There is no overlap with the required functionality (reading 5 integers, summing evens). This is not a minor implementation error but a fundamental misalignment with the assignment requirements.

evidence.note: Student reads 3 double values (v0, v1, t) instead of reading 5 integers as required by the problem.

evidence.snippet:
double a = ( v1 - v0 ) / t ;

System.out.println ( "The average acceleration is " + a ) ;
evidence.note: Student calculates and outputs acceleration (a physics formula) instead of summing even numbers. This is the wrong problem entirely.

misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (average acceleration) instead of summing even integers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time, instead of reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones as required. This indicates a misunderstanding or disregard of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and prints the average acceleration ( (v1 - v0) / t ).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, check which of them are even (n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of those even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompts for "v0, v1, and t" instead of 5 integers.
Program reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers.
Program computes (v1 - v0) / t and prints "The average acceleration is".
There is no loop, no conditional even check, and no accumulator for the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem statement or reuse of an unrelated solution template without adapting it to the current task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and rewrite the program so that it: (1) asks for 5 integers, (2) reads them (e.g., in a loop), (3) checks each with n % 2 == 0, (4) keeps a running sum of only the even numbers, and (5) prints the final sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code (prompt, variable names, formula, and output message) clearly targets a physics acceleration problem, with no elements related to reading 5 integers or summing even numbers.

evidence.snippet:
System.out.print ( "Enter v0, v1, and t: " ) ; // prompt

double v0 = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // starting velocity
double v1 = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // final velocity
double t = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // time

double a = ( v1 - v0 ) / t ; // compute acceleration

System.out.println ( "The average acceleration is " + a ) ; // output
evidence.note: The code prompts for v0, v1, and t, reads 3 doubles, computes acceleration, and prints it, which does not match the requirement to read 5 integers and sum the even ones.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Goal (Calculation instead of Iterative Summation)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the average acceleration based on three inputs (v0, v1, t), completely ignoring the assignment requirement, which was to read five integers and calculate the sum of the even numbers among them.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the goal was to calculate average acceleration using a kinematic formula, possibly confusing this task with a previous or different assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task required reading exactly five numerical inputs from the user, checking each one for evenness (using the modulo operator), and accumulating only the even numbers into a total sum.
symptoms: Code implements an entirely different calculation (acceleration)
Reads three double-precision floating-point numbers instead of five integers
Lacks any loop structure required to process five inputs iteratively
Lacks conditional logic (if statement) and modulus check (% 2)
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to read or adhere to the problem statement instructions.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Reread the problem statement carefully: 'Write a program that reads 5 integers from the user and prints the sum of only the even numbers.' Focus on the required input count (5), input type (integer), control flow (loop), and filtering logic (even check).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student code solves an entirely different problem than the one specified in the prompt. This is a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment objective.

evidence.snippet:
System.out.print ( "Enter v0, v1, and t: " ) ; // prompt

        double v0 = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // starting velocity
        double v1 = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // final velocity
        double t = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // time

        double a = ( v1 - v0 ) / t ; // compute acceleration

        System.out.println ( "The average acceleration is " + a ) ; // output
evidence.note: The entire program logic calculates average acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Number and Type of Input
misconceptions.description: The student reads three inputs of type `double` (`nextDouble()`) instead of reading five inputs of type `int` (`nextInt()`) as required by the prompt.
misconceptions.student_belief: Inputs for this task require floating-point values (doubles), and only three inputs are necessary.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The prompt specified 5 integers. The program must use `input.nextInt()` five times (ideally within a loop) and use `int` variables.
symptoms: Use of `nextDouble()`
Only three variables defined (`v0`, `v1`, `t`)
Input prompt requests 'v0, v1, and t'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Inherited from the primary misconception (solving the wrong problem). The student used the input scheme for the acceleration problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure the input method matches the required data type (integer) and that the number of inputs (5) is correct.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly reads three doubles and assigns them to acceleration-related variables.

evidence.snippet:
double v0 = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // starting velocity
        double v1 = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // final velocity
        double t = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // time
evidence.note: Reads three doubles instead of five integers.

misconceptions.name: Problem Misinterpretation - Wrong Assignment Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a solution to a completely different problem (calculating acceleration) instead of the assigned problem (sum of even numbers). This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding or misread of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should calculate acceleration from velocity and time inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers and summing only the even-valued numbers among them.
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration formula: (v1 - v0) / t
Reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
Output is 'The average acceleration is' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'
No loop, no even-number checking logic present
misconceptions.root_cause: Student did not carefully read or understand the assignment specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. You need to: (1) read 5 integers, (2) use a loop, (3) check if each number is even using `n % 2 == 0`, (4) accumulate a running sum of only even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves a physics problem (acceleration calculation) which is completely unrelated to the assignment (sum of even numbers). This is unmistakable evidence of problem misinterpretation.

evidence.note: Prompt asks for physics variables (initial velocity, final velocity, time) instead of 5 integers
Reads only 3 values as doubles; assignment requires 5 integers
Calculates acceleration; no logic for checking even numbers or summing
Output is acceleration value, not the sum of even numbers as required
